sources.title: The Wild Party (1929) CLARA BOWüçï FREDRIC MARCHüçï PRE-CODE HOLLYWOOD
sources.description:
PizzaFLIX Presents CLASSIC MOVIE MONDAY
Stars: Clara Bow, Fredric March, Marceline Day
Directed by: Dorothy Arzner
üçï THE ‚ÄúIT GIRL‚Äù SPEAKSüçï 
The electrifying Clara Bow breaks the sound barrier with her daring ‚ÄúAll-Talking‚Äù debut! Bursting with flirtation, folly, and first loves, this rip-roaring collegiate romp co-stars Fredric March and Marceline Day, with direction by Dorothy Arzner ‚Äî the first woman to direct a Hollywood sound film.

Set in the wild, freewheeling world of college life, this film captures the energy, rebellion, and romantic entanglements of young women as they navigate newfound independence.

With a screenplay by Ethel Doherty and a story by Samuel Hopkins Adams, this film also features cinematography by Victor Milner and a dynamic soundtrack that helped usher in the era of talking pictures.

Be sure to LIKE, COMMENT, and SUBSCRIBE for more rare, vintage films every WEEK on PizzaFLIX.

sources.title: The Wild Party (1929)
sources.description: I've been researching newly public domain films from 1929 and earlier, so I'm uploading the best possible copies that I can find. Director Dorothy Arzner was one of the few women directors working in Hollywood at the time of release, and was almost certainly the only lesbian director during that period. The Wild Party is the oldest work in her filmography that still exists and was a huge box office hit. While reviews were decent, this film about a college girl falling for a professor is more remembered now as the talking debut for star Clara Bow.¬†

metadata.Plot: Wild girls at a college pay more attention to parties than their classes. But when one party girl, Stella Ames, goes too far at a local bar and gets in trouble, her professor has to rescue her. Gossip linking the two escalates until Stella proves she is decent by shielding an innocent girl and winning the professor's respect.
metadata.Writer: Samuel Hopkins Adams, E. Lloyd Sheldon, George Marion Jr.
metadata.Actors: Clara Bow, Fredric March, Marceline Day
